issues.description: Template file src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java is structurally invalid and does not match the problem statement or the solution. The template declares a class named AnimalFarm instead of Farm and contains a duplicated 'package' declaration and a nested/duplicated class declaration inside a method, producing malformed Java source that will not compile. This directly conflicts with the problem statement (which requires a class named Farm with specific methods/attributes) and with the solution (which provides a Farm class). As written, the template prevents students from compiling the project or implementing the intended Farm class and its methods (addAnimal, feedAllAnimals, singFarmSong, getters/setters), causing major confusion and blocking progress.
issues.suggested_fix: Replace the broken template file with a proper Farm class stub that matches the problem UML and the solution. Specifically: (1) Use the correct class name 'Farm' (public class Farm) in package de.tum.cit.ase; (2) remove the duplicated 'package' declaration and any nested/duplicated class declarations so the file is valid Java; (3) provide stubs (or minimal valid implementations) for the required members: private List<Animal> animals; a no-arg constructor initializing the ArrayList; getAnimals()/setAnimals(List<Animal>); addAnimal(Animal); feedAllAnimals(); singFarmSong(); and a private helper singFarmSongVerse(Animal). Keeping method bodies as TODOs is fine, but the class must be syntactically correct so students can compile and implement the exercise.

issues.description: The problem statement and solution refer to a class named "Farm" (the UML and tasks explicitly define a Farm class with methods like addAnimal, feedAllAnimals, singFarmSong), but the template repository's file Farm.java declares a public class named "AnimalFarm" instead of "Farm". This mismatch breaks the direct mapping from the problem description to the starter code (students will look for a Farm class and may be confused or unable to find/implement the expected API), and also diverges from the solution implementation which uses the name Farm.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the class in the template file to match the problem statement and solution: change the public class declaration from 'public class AnimalFarm' to 'public class Farm' (and update any internal references accordingly). Ensure Farm.java defines the expected methods/attributes (addAnimal, feedAllAnimals, singFarmSong, and the animals list) so students can clearly map the UML/tasks to the starter code.
